contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox astronaut | name = Vladimir Alekseyevich Solovyov | image = | type = Cosmonaut | nationality = [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] / [[Russia]]n | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|11|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[USSR]] | occupation = [[Flight engineer]] | selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1978|1978]] | time = 361d 22h 49m | mission = [[Soyuz T-10]], [[Soyuz T-15]] | insignia = | awards = [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] (2) }} '''Vladimir Alekseyevich Solovyov''' ({{lang-ru|Влади́мир Алексе́евич Соловьёв}}; born November 11, 1946) is a former [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[cosmonaut]]. He was selected as a cosmonaut on December 1, 1978 and flew as Flight Engineer on [[Soyuz T-10]] and [[Soyuz T-15]], spending a total of 361 days, 22 hours, 49 minutes in space. His first flight, Soyuz T-10, took off on February 8, 1984, to join [[Salyut 7]]. The crew spent ten months (nearly 237 days) performing numerous medical and space manufacturing experiments. They came down aboard [[Soyuz T-11]] on October 2, 1984. Solovyov's second flight was aboard Soyuz T-15, taking off on March 13, 1986 and coming back aboard the same craft on July 16, 1986, 125 days later. During the T-15 mission, the crew transferred equipment from Salyut-7 to the new [[Mir space station]]; they were the last aboard the former and the first aboard the latter. Solovyov then became the Mir flight director (Russian Mission Control) for several years. He retired on February 18, 1994 but came back to head the Russian segment of the [[International Space Station]] (ISS). Solovyov is married and has two children. He was awarded: * Twice [[Hero of the Soviet Union]] (October 2, 1984 and July 16, 1986); * [[Pilot-Cosmonaut of the USSR]]; * [[Order of Honour (Russian Federation)]]; * [[Order of Friendship|Order of Friendship (Russian Federation)]]; * Two [[Order of Lenin|Orders of Lenin]] (USSR); * [[Medal "For Merit in Space Exploration"]] (Russian Federation); * Knight of the [[Legion of Honour]] (France); * [[Kirti Chakra]] (India). ==External links== * [http://www.msnbc.com/news/537171.asp?0sp=n3b6&cp1=1 MSNBC - Witness to Mir’s beginning and end] (2001) * [http://newsfromrussia.com/science/2004/06/25/54552.html Pravda - Experts search for cause of spacesuit leak] (2004) {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Soloviyov, Vladimir Alekseyevich | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Soviet cosmonaut | DATE OF BIRTH = November 11, 1946 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soloviyov, Vladimir Alekseyevich}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Moscow]] [[Category:Soviet cosmonauts]] [[Category:Heroes of the Soviet Union]] {{russia-bio-stub}} {{astronaut-stub}}
